title: Mercedes boss Toto Wolff says Lewis Hamilton is 'scarred' by childhood discrimination
text:
Lewis Hamilton is still wounded by the racist abuse he suffered as a boy, according to his Mercedes boss Toto Wolff.

The British racer could add a sixth world championship title in the thin, sooty air of Mexico City - another milestone in a journey from Stevenage council estate to a £200million fortune.

But 12 years after he arrived in Formula One like a starburst, Hamilton is still the first and only black driver on the grid.

Toto Wolff praised Lewis Hamilton for dealing with racism and said he has a 'strong personality'

Wolff said: 'When Lewis was younger he was the only black kid among the white kids and I know he was racially abused on the track. If that happens to an eight-year-old, or a 10-year-old, it just leaves scars that will not go away.

'If, as a child, you have had to overcome abuse and discrimination it makes you stronger. But on the other side it also leaves scars.

'Today, Lewis has a good and mature perspective but the scars are certainly there. That is not the only motivating factor for him - those scars are a witness to having survived. We are not very diverse in Formula One, and I have learned through Lewis to accept that it is difficult to overcome discrimination from time to time.

The five-time world champion was racially abused on the track when he was a junior karting

Hamilton will win his sixth world championship if he outscorers Valtteri Bottas by 14 points

HOW LEWIS HAMILTON CAN CLINCH SIXTH WORLD TITLE - Win and record the fastest lap with Mercedes team-mate Valtteri Bottas finishing lower than third - Win with Bottas lower than fourth - Finish second and record the fastest lap with Bottas lower than seventh - Finish second with Bottas lower than eighth if Bottas sets fastest lap - Finish third and record the fastest lap with Bottas lower than eighth - Finish third with Bottas finishing lower than ninth

'Racism has a subtle side and it is painful. Lewis wears his heart on his sleeve, he has opinions, and by expressing them he will always run the risk of polarising opinion.'

Hamilton, 34, has regularly called for more diversity in the sport.

When penalised by the stewards in Monaco in 2011, he wondered aloud: 'Is it cos I'm black? That's what Ali G says.'

Hamilton's minder, Lloyd, is one of few other black faces regularly seen in the paddock.

On the track, Hamilton must outscore his Mercedes team-mate Valtteri Bottas by 14 points this weekend to wrap up title No 6, which would leave him behind only Michael Schumacher, on seven, in the all-time list.

Although Hamilton was fastest in practice on Friday, recent history suggests this is unlikely to happen.

Autodromo Hermanos Rodriguez is not a track that has been kind to Mercedes in recent years.

Hamilton has finished fourth and ninth on his last two visits and that would not be enough to put Bottas out of his misery.

Indeed, Hamilton must finish on the podium to have any chance of taking the crown. Otherwise, it goes on to Austin a week on Sunday.

He came third in the Japanese Grand Prix, finishing behind Sebastian Vettel and winner Bottas

He is without his race engineer Pete Bonnington, who is missing this grand prix and the next for a medical procedure.

Bonnington is known to us for his unruffled radio voice in the heat of battle. Radio duties will be taken over by Marcus Dudley, Hamilton's performance engineer.

Hamilton, who arrived in Mexico having stirred up controversy by calling on his 13million Instagram followers to embrace veganism, remains most comfortable in the sanctuary of his cockpit.

His determination to add more wins and new glories is unflagging even going into his 247th race. 'Punching out these performances weekend in, weekend out is such a hard task,' he acknowledged.

'It doesn't matter if I get it done here as long as I get it done. There are still plenty of points on the table and I've got to deliver.'
description: JONATHAN McEVOY IN MEXICO CITY: Hamilton broke down racial barriers as a junior karter en route to the summit of Formula One, but he remains the sport's only black driver.
authors: Jonathan Mcevoy For The Daily Mail
